âœï¸The structure of high-performing data teams is evolving â€” and context is everything.ğŸ§ As a CDO in the banking sector, I see firsthand how the right data team composition depends heavily on company size, regulatory environment, and data maturity.The recent benchmark shared on the balance between Insights (46%), Data Engineering (43%), and Machine Learning (11%) resonates â€” but Iâ€™d add a few reflections based on experience leading data transformations in both traditional and digital banking environments:1. In early maturity stages, especially in highly regulated industries like banking, data engineering and governance are foundational. Without robust pipelines, metadata management, lineage tracking, and data quality controls, insights are unreliable â€” and regulatory risk increases.I often tell teams: â€œWe earn the right to do ML by getting the basics right first.â€2. As maturity builds, we focus on embedding analytics across the business â€” especially in risk, fraud, customer experience, and credit. This is where a strong layer of product analysts and embedded BI starts driving tangible business impact.3. At scale, roles like data product managers, governance leads, and ML engineers become critical â€” not just to deliver models, but to ensure theyâ€™re explainable, monitored, and integrated into decision systems.And increasingly, weâ€™re seeing the need for platform thinking: building reusable data products, not just bespoke dashboards.AI-native tools are already reshaping whatâ€™s possible, but I believe the core value still lies in clarity, trust, and alignment between data and business goals.ğŸ’¡No one structure fits all â€” but understanding your current stage helps you build the right team, at the right time, to deliver real impact.ğŸ«µAnd hey â€” if you made it to the end: Iâ€™m currently hiring. âœï¸The structure of high-performing data teams is evolving â€” and context is everything.ğŸ§ As a CDO in the banking sector, I see firsthand how the right data team composition depends heavily on company size, regulatory environment, and data maturity.The recent benchmark shared on the balance between Insights (46%), Data Engineering (43%), and Machine Learning (11%) resonates â€” but Iâ€™d add a few reflections based on experience leading data transformations in both traditional and digital banking environments:1. In early maturity stages, especially in highly regulated industries like banking, data engineering and governance are foundational. Without robust pipelines, metadata management, lineage tracking, and data quality controls, insights are unreliable â€” and regulatory risk increases.I often tell teams: â€œWe earn the right to do ML by getting the basics right first.â€2. As maturity builds, we focus on embedding analytics across the business â€” especially in risk, fraud, customer experience, and credit. This is where a strong layer of product analysts and embedded BI starts driving tangible business impact.3. At scale, roles like data product managers, governance leads, and ML engineers become critical â€” not just to deliver models, but to ensure theyâ€™re explainable, monitored, and integrated into decision systems.And increasingly, weâ€™re seeing the need for platform thinking: building reusable data products, not just bespoke dashboards.AI-native tools are already reshaping whatâ€™s possible, but I believe the core value still lies in clarity, trust, and alignment between data and business goals.ğŸ’¡No one structure fits all â€” but understanding your current stage helps you build the right team, at the right time, to deliver real impact.ğŸ«µAnd hey â€” if you made it to the end: Iâ€™m currently hiring. âœï¸The structure of high-performing data teams is evolving â€” and context is everything.ğŸ§ As a CDO in the banking sector, I see firsthand how the right data team composition depends heavily on company size, regulatory environment, and data maturity.The recent benchmark shared on the balance between Insights (46%), Data Engineering (43%), and Machine Learning (11%) resonates â€” but Iâ€™d add a few reflections based on experience leading data transformations in both traditional and digital banking environments:1. In early maturity stages, especially in highly regulated industries like banking, data engineering and governance are foundational. Without robust pipelines, metadata management, lineage tracking, and data quality controls, insights are unreliable â€” and regulatory risk increases.I often tell teams: â€œWe earn the right to do ML by getting the basics right first.â€2. As maturity builds, we focus on embedding analytics across the business â€” especially in risk, fraud, customer experience, and credit. This is where a strong layer of product analysts and embedded BI starts driving tangible business impact.3. At scale, roles like data product managers, governance leads, and ML engineers become critical â€” not just to deliver models, but to ensure theyâ€™re explainable, monitored, and integrated into decision systems.And increasingly, weâ€™re seeing the need for platform thinking: building reusable data products, not just bespoke dashboards.AI-native tools are already reshaping whatâ€™s possible, but I believe the core value still lies in clarity, trust, and alignment between data and business goals.ğŸ’¡No one structure fits all â€” but understanding your current stage helps you build the right team, at the right time, to deliver real impact.ğŸ«µAnd hey â€” if you made it to the end: Iâ€™m currently hiring. âœï¸The structure of high-performing data teams is evolving â€” and context is everything.ğŸ§ As a CDO in the banking sector, I see firsthand how the right data team composition depends heavily on company size, regulatory environment, and data maturity.The recent benchmark shared on the balance between Insights (46%), Data Engineering (43%), and Machine Learning (11%) resonates â€” but Iâ€™d add a few reflections based on experience leading data transformations in both traditional and digital banking environments:1. In early maturity stages, especially in highly regulated industries like banking, data engineering and governance are foundational. Without robust pipelines, metadata management, lineage tracking, and data quality controls, insights are unreliable â€” and regulatory risk increases.I often tell teams: â€œWe earn the right to do ML by getting the basics right first.â€2. As maturity builds, we focus on embedding analytics across the business â€” especially in risk, fraud, customer experience, and credit. This is where a strong layer of product analysts and embedded BI starts driving tangible business impact.3. At scale, roles like data product managers, governance leads, and ML engineers become critical â€” not just to deliver models, but to ensure theyâ€™re explainable, monitored, and integrated into decision systems.And increasingly, weâ€™re seeing the need for platform thinking: building reusable data products, not just bespoke dashboards.AI-native tools are already reshaping whatâ€™s possible, but I believe the core value still lies in clarity, trust, and alignment between data and business goals.ğŸ’¡No one structure fits all â€” but understanding your current stage helps you build the right team, at the right time, to deliver real impact.ğŸ«µAnd hey â€” if you made it to the end: Iâ€™m currently hiring. âœï¸The structure of high-performing data teams is evolving â€” and context is everything.ğŸ§ As a CDO in the banking sector, I see firsthand how the right data team composition depends heavily on company size, regulatory environment, and data maturity.The recent benchmark shared on the balance between Insights (46%), Data Engineering (43%), and Machine Learning (11%) resonates â€” but Iâ€™d add a few reflections based on experience leading data transformations in both traditional and digital banking environments:1. In early maturity stages, especially in highly regulated industries like banking, data engineering and governance are foundational. Without robust pipelines, metadata management, lineage tracking, and data quality controls, insights are unreliable â€” and regulatory risk increases.I often tell teams: â€œWe earn the right to do ML by getting the basics right first.â€2. âœï¸The structure of high-performing data teams is evolving â€” and context is everything.ğŸ§ As a CDO in the banking sector, I see firsthand how the right data team composition depends heavily on company size, regulatory environment, and data maturity.The recent benchmark shared on the balance between Insights (46%), Data Engineering (43%), and Machine Learning (11%) resonates â€” but Iâ€™d add a few reflections based on experience leading data transformations in both traditional and digital banking environments:1. Without robust pipelines, metadata management, lineage tracking, and data quality controls, insights are unreliable â€” and regulatory risk increases.I often tell teams: â€œWe earn the right to do ML by getting the basics right first.â€2. As maturity builds, we focus on embedding analytics across the business â€” especially in risk, fraud, customer experience, and credit. This is where a strong layer of product analysts and embedded BI starts driving tangible business impact.3. At scale, roles like data product managers, governance leads, and ML engineers become critical â€” not just to deliver models, but to ensure theyâ€™re explainable, monitored, and integrated into decision systems.And increasingly, weâ€™re seeing the need for platform thinking: building reusable data products, not just bespoke dashboards.AI-native tools are already reshaping whatâ€™s possible, but I believe the core value still lies in clarity, trust, and alignment between data and business goals.ğŸ’¡No one structure fits all â€” but understanding your current stage helps you build the right team, at the right time, to deliver real impact.ğŸ«µAnd hey â€” if you made it to the end: Iâ€™m currently hiring. âœï¸The structure of high-performing data teams is evolving â€” and context is everything.ğŸ§ As a CDO in the banking sector, I see firsthand how the right data team composition depends heavily on company size, regulatory environment, and data maturity.The recent benchmark shared on the balance between Insights (46%), Data Engineering (43%), and Machine Learning (11%) resonates â€” but Iâ€™d add a few reflections based on experience leading data transformations in both traditional and digital banking environments:1. In early maturity stages, especially in highly regulated industries like banking, data engineering and governance are foundational. Without robust pipelines, metadata management, lineage tracking, and data quality controls, insights are unreliable â€” and regulatory risk increases.I often tell teams: â€œWe earn the right to do ML by getting the basics right first.â€2. As maturity builds, we focus on embedding analytics across the business â€” especially in risk, fraud, customer experience, and credit. This is where a strong layer of product analysts and embedded BI starts driving tangible business impact.3. At scale, roles like data product managers, governance leads, and ML engineers become critical â€” not just to deliver models, but to ensure theyâ€™re explainable, monitored, and integrated into decision systems.And increasingly, weâ€™re seeing the need for platform thinking: building reusable data products, not just bespoke dashboards.AI-native tools are already reshaping whatâ€™s possible, but I believe the core value still lies in clarity, trust, and alignment between data and business goals.ğŸ’¡No one structure fits all â€” but understanding your current stage helps you build the right team, at the right time, to deliver real impact.ğŸ«µAnd hey â€” if you made it to the end: Iâ€™m currently hiring. Weâ€™re building something exciting, and Iâ€™m looking for data stewards, data engineers, and data scientists to join our team.DM me if youâ€™re curious.hashtag#CDO hashtag#BankingInnovation hashtag#DataGovernance hashtag#AnalyticsEngineering hashtag#DataStrategy hashtag#DataLeadership hashtag#AIinBanking

âœï¸The structure of high-performing data teams is evolving â€” and context is everything.ğŸ§ As a CDO in the banking sector, I see firsthand how the right data team composition depends heavily on company size, regulatory environment, and data maturity.The recent benchmark shared on the balance between Insights (46%), Data Engineering (43%), and Machine Learning (11%) resonates â€” but Iâ€™d add a few reflections based on experience leading data transformations in both traditional and digital banking environments:1. In early maturity stages, especially in highly regulated industries like banking, data engineering and governance are foundational. Without robust pipelines, metadata management, lineage tracking, and data quality controls, insights are unreliable â€” and regulatory risk increases.I often tell teams: â€œWe earn the right to do ML by getting the basics right first.â€2. As maturity builds, we focus on embedding analytics across the business â€” especially in risk, fraud, customer experience, and credit. This is where a strong layer of product analysts and embedded BI starts driving tangible business impact.3. At scale, roles like data product managers, governance leads, and ML engineers become critical â€” not just to deliver models, but to ensure theyâ€™re explainable, monitored, and integrated into decision systems.And increasingly, weâ€™re seeing the need for platform thinking: building reusable data products, not just bespoke dashboards.AI-native tools are already reshaping whatâ€™s possible, but I believe the core value still lies in clarity, trust, and alignment between data and business goals.ğŸ’¡No one structure fits all â€” but understanding your current stage helps you build the right team, at the right time, to deliver real impact.ğŸ«µAnd hey â€” if you made it to the end: Iâ€™m currently hiring. âœï¸The structure of high-performing data teams is evolving â€” and context is everything.ğŸ§ As a CDO in the banking sector, I see firsthand how the right data team composition depends heavily on company size, regulatory environment, and data maturity.The recent benchmark shared on the balance between Insights (46%), Data Engineering (43%), and Machine Learning (11%) resonates â€” but Iâ€™d add a few reflections based on experience leading data transformations in both traditional and digital banking environments:1. In early maturity stages, especially in highly regulated industries like banking, data engineering and governance are foundational. Without robust pipelines, metadata management, lineage tracking, and data quality controls, insights are unreliable â€” and regulatory risk increases.I often tell teams: â€œWe earn the right to do ML by getting the basics right first.â€2. As maturity builds, we focus on embedding analytics across the business â€” especially in risk, fraud, customer experience, and credit. This is where a strong layer of product analysts and embedded BI starts driving tangible business impact.3. At scale, roles like data product managers, governance leads, and ML engineers become critical â€” not just to deliver models, but to ensure theyâ€™re explainable, monitored, and integrated into decision systems.And increasingly, weâ€™re seeing the need for platform thinking: building reusable data products, not just bespoke dashboards.AI-native tools are already reshaping whatâ€™s possible, but I believe the core value still lies in clarity, trust, and alignment between data and business goals.ğŸ’¡No one structure fits all â€” but understanding your current stage helps you build the right team, at the right time, to deliver real impact.ğŸ«µAnd hey â€” if you made it to the end: Iâ€™m currently hiring. âœï¸The structure of high-performing data teams is evolving â€” and context is everything.ğŸ§ As a CDO in the banking sector, I see firsthand how the right data team composition depends heavily on company size, regulatory environment, and data maturity.The recent benchmark shared on the balance between Insights (46%), Data Engineering (43%), and Machine Learning (11%) resonates â€” but Iâ€™d add a few reflections based on experience leading data transformations in both traditional and digital banking environments:1. In early maturity stages, especially in highly regulated industries like banking, data engineering and governance are foundational. Without robust pipelines, metadata management, lineage tracking, and data quality controls, insights are unreliable â€” and regulatory risk increases.I often tell teams: â€œWe earn the right to do ML by getting the basics right first.â€2. As maturity builds, we focus on embedding analytics across the business â€” especially in risk, fraud, customer experience, and credit. This is where a strong layer of product analysts and embedded BI starts driving tangible business impact.3. At scale, roles like data product managers, governance leads, and ML engineers become critical â€” not just to deliver models, but to ensure theyâ€™re explainable, monitored, and integrated into decision systems.And increasingly, weâ€™re seeing the need for platform thinking: building reusable data products, not just bespoke dashboards.AI-native tools are already reshaping whatâ€™s possible, but I believe the core value still lies in clarity, trust, and alignment between data and business goals.ğŸ’¡No one structure fits all â€” but understanding your current stage helps you build the right team, at the right time, to deliver real impact.ğŸ«µAnd hey â€” if you made it to the end: Iâ€™m currently hiring. Weâ€™re building something exciting, and Iâ€™m looking for data stewards, data engineers, and data scientists to join our team.DM me if youâ€™re curious.hashtag#CDO hashtag#BankingInnovation hashtag#DataGovernance hashtag#AnalyticsEngineering hashtag#DataStrategy hashtag#DataLeadership hashtag#AIinBanking

âœï¸The structure of high-performing data teams is evolving â€” and context is everything.ğŸ§ As a CDO in the banking sector, I see firsthand how the right data team composition depends heavily on company size, regulatory environment, and data maturity.The recent benchmark shared on the balance between Insights (46%), Data Engineering (43%), and Machine Learning (11%) resonates â€” but Iâ€™d add a few reflections based on experience leading data transformations in both traditional and digital banking environments:1. In early maturity stages, especially in highly regulated industries like banking, data engineering and governance are foundational. Without robust pipelines, metadata management, lineage tracking, and data quality controls, insights are unreliable â€” and regulatory risk increases.I often tell teams: â€œWe earn the right to do ML by getting the basics right first.â€2. As maturity builds, we focus on embedding analytics across the business â€” especially in risk, fraud, customer experience, and credit. This is where a strong layer of product analysts and embedded BI starts driving tangible business impact.3. At scale, roles like data product managers, governance leads, and ML engineers become critical â€” not just to deliver models, but to ensure theyâ€™re explainable, monitored, and integrated into decision systems.And increasingly, weâ€™re seeing the need for platform thinking: building reusable data products, not just bespoke dashboards.AI-native tools are already reshaping whatâ€™s possible, but I believe the core value still lies in clarity, trust, and alignment between data and business goals.ğŸ’¡No one structure fits all â€” but understanding your current stage helps you build the right team, at the right time, to deliver real impact.ğŸ«µAnd hey â€” if you made it to the end: Iâ€™m currently hiring. âœï¸The structure of high-performing data teams is evolving â€” and context is everything.ğŸ§ As a CDO in the banking sector, I see firsthand how the right data team composition depends heavily on company size, regulatory environment, and data maturity.The recent benchmark shared on the balance between Insights (46%), Data Engineering (43%), and Machine Learning (11%) resonates â€” but Iâ€™d add a few reflections based on experience leading data transformations in both traditional and digital banking environments:1. In early maturity stages, especially in highly regulated industries like banking, data engineering and governance are foundational. Without robust pipelines, metadata management, lineage tracking, and data quality controls, insights are unreliable â€” and regulatory risk increases.I often tell teams: â€œWe earn the right to do ML by getting the basics right first.â€2. As maturity builds, we focus on embedding analytics across the business â€” especially in risk, fraud, customer experience, and credit. This is where a strong layer of product analysts and embedded BI starts driving tangible business impact.3. At scale, roles like data product managers, governance leads, and ML engineers become critical â€” not just to deliver models, but to ensure theyâ€™re explainable, monitored, and integrated into decision systems.And increasingly, weâ€™re seeing the need for platform thinking: building reusable data products, not just bespoke dashboards.AI-native tools are already reshaping whatâ€™s possible, but I believe the core value still lies in clarity, trust, and alignment between data and business goals.ğŸ’¡No one structure fits all â€” but understanding your current stage helps you build the right team, at the right time, to deliver real impact.ğŸ«µAnd hey â€” if you made it to the end: Iâ€™m currently hiring. âœï¸The structure of high-performing data teams is evolving â€” and context is everything.ğŸ§ As a CDO in the banking sector, I see firsthand how the right data team composition depends heavily on company size, regulatory environment, and data maturity.The recent benchmark shared on the balance between Insights (46%), Data Engineering (43%), and Machine Learning (11%) resonates â€” but Iâ€™d add a few reflections based on experience leading data transformations in both traditional and digital banking environments:1. In early maturity stages, especially in highly regulated industries like banking, data engineering and governance are foundational. Without robust pipelines, metadata management, lineage tracking, and data quality controls, insights are unreliable â€” and regulatory risk increases.I often tell teams: â€œWe earn the right to do ML by getting the basics right first.â€2. As maturity builds, we focus on embedding analytics across the business â€” especially in risk, fraud, customer experience, and credit. This is where a strong layer of product analysts and embedded BI starts driving tangible business impact.3. At scale, roles like data product managers, governance leads, and ML engineers become critical â€” not just to deliver models, but to ensure theyâ€™re explainable, monitored, and integrated into decision systems.And increasingly, weâ€™re seeing the need for platform thinking: building reusable data products, not just bespoke dashboards.AI-native tools are already reshaping whatâ€™s possible, but I believe the core value still lies in clarity, trust, and alignment between data and business goals.ğŸ’¡No one structure fits all â€” but understanding your current stage helps you build the right team, at the right time, to deliver real impact.ğŸ«µAnd hey â€” if you made it to the end: Iâ€™m currently hiring. Weâ€™re building something exciting, and Iâ€™m looking for data stewards, data engineers, and data scientists to join our team.DM me if youâ€™re curious.hashtag#CDO hashtag#BankingInnovation hashtag#DataGovernance hashtag#AnalyticsEngineering hashtag#DataStrategy hashtag#DataLeadership hashtag#AIinBanking

At scale, roles like data product managers, governance leads, and ML engineers become critical â€” not just to deliver models, but to ensure theyâ€™re explainable, monitored, and integrated into decision systems.And increasingly, weâ€™re seeing the need for platform thinking: building reusable data products, not just bespoke dashboards.AI-native tools are already reshaping whatâ€™s possible, but I believe the core value still lies in clarity, trust, and alignment between data and business goals.ğŸ’¡No one structure fits all â€” but understanding your current stage helps you build the right team, at the right time, to deliver real impact.ğŸ«µAnd hey â€” if you made it to the end: Iâ€™m currently hiring. âœï¸The structure of high-performing data teams is evolving â€” and context is everything.ğŸ§ As a CDO in the banking sector, I see firsthand how the right data team composition depends heavily on company size, regulatory environment, and data maturity.The recent benchmark shared on the balance between Insights (46%), Data Engineering (43%), and Machine Learning (11%) resonates â€” but Iâ€™d add a few reflections based on experience leading data transformations in both traditional and digital banking environments:1. In early maturity stages, especially in highly regulated industries like banking, data engineering and governance are foundational. Without robust pipelines, metadata management, lineage tracking, and data quality controls, insights are unreliable â€” and regulatory risk increases.I often tell teams: â€œWe earn the right to do ML by getting the basics right first.â€2. As maturity builds, we focus on embedding analytics across the business â€” especially in risk, fraud, customer experience, and credit. This is where a strong layer of product analysts and embedded BI starts driving tangible business impact.3. At scale, roles like data product managers, governance leads, and ML engineers become critical â€” not just to deliver models, but to ensure theyâ€™re explainable, monitored, and integrated into decision systems.And increasingly, weâ€™re seeing the need for platform thinking: building reusable data products, not just bespoke dashboards.AI-native tools are already reshaping whatâ€™s possible, but I believe the core value still lies in clarity, trust, and alignment between data and business goals.ğŸ’¡No one structure fits all â€” but understanding your current stage helps you build the right team, at the right time, to deliver real impact.ğŸ«µAnd hey â€” if you made it to the end: Iâ€™m currently hiring. âœï¸The structure of high-performing data teams is evolving â€” and context is everything.ğŸ§ As a CDO in the banking sector, I see firsthand how the right data team composition depends heavily on company size, regulatory environment, and data maturity.The recent benchmark shared on the balance between Insights (46%), Data Engineering (43%), and Machine Learning (11%) resonates â€” but Iâ€™d add a few reflections based on experience leading data transformations in both traditional and digital banking environments:1. In early maturity stages, especially in highly regulated industries like banking, data engineering and governance are foundational. Without robust pipelines, metadata management, lineage tracking, and data quality controls, insights are unreliable â€” and regulatory risk increases.I often tell teams: â€œWe earn the right to do ML by getting the basics right first.â€2. As maturity builds, we focus on embedding analytics across the business â€” especially in risk, fraud, customer experience, and credit. This is where a strong layer of product analysts and embedded BI starts driving tangible business impact.3. At scale, roles like data product managers, governance leads, and ML engineers become critical â€” not just to deliver models, but to ensure theyâ€™re explainable, monitored, and integrated into decision systems.And increasingly, weâ€™re seeing the need for platform thinking: building reusable data products, not just bespoke dashboards.AI-native tools are already reshaping whatâ€™s possible, but I believe the core value still lies in clarity, trust, and alignment between data and business goals.ğŸ’¡No one structure fits all â€” but understanding your current stage helps you build the right team, at the right time, to deliver real impact.ğŸ«µAnd hey â€” if you made it to the end: Iâ€™m currently hiring. âœï¸The structure of high-performing data teams is evolving â€” and context is everything.ğŸ§ As a CDO in the banking sector, I see firsthand how the right data team composition depends heavily on company size, regulatory environment, and data maturity.The recent benchmark shared on the balance between Insights (46%), Data Engineering (43%), and Machine Learning (11%) resonates â€” but Iâ€™d add a few reflections based on experience leading data transformations in both traditional and digital banking environments:1. Without robust pipelines, metadata management, lineage tracking, and data quality controls, insights are unreliable â€” and regulatory risk increases.I often tell teams: â€œWe earn the right to do ML by getting the basics right first.â€2. As maturity builds, we focus on embedding analytics across the business â€” especially in risk, fraud, customer experience, and credit. This is where a strong layer of product analysts and embedded BI starts driving tangible business impact.3. At scale, roles like data product managers, governance leads, and ML engineers become critical â€” not just to deliver models, but to ensure theyâ€™re explainable, monitored, and integrated into decision systems.And increasingly, weâ€™re seeing the need for platform thinking: building reusable data products, not just bespoke dashboards.AI-native tools are already reshaping whatâ€™s possible, but I believe the core value still lies in clarity, trust, and alignment between data and business goals.ğŸ’¡No one structure fits all â€” but understanding your current stage helps you build the right team, at the right time, to deliver real impact.ğŸ«µAnd hey â€” if you made it to the end: Iâ€™m currently hiring. âœï¸The structure of high-performing data teams is evolving â€” and context is everything.ğŸ§ As a CDO in the banking sector, I see firsthand how the right data team composition depends heavily on company size, regulatory environment, and data maturity.The recent benchmark shared on the balance between Insights (46%), Data Engineering (43%), and Machine Learning (11%) resonates â€” but Iâ€™d add a few reflections based on experience leading data transformations in both traditional and digital banking environments:1. In early maturity stages, especially in highly regulated industries like banking, data engineering and governance are foundational. Without robust pipelines, metadata management, lineage tracking, and data quality controls, insights are unreliable â€” and regulatory risk increases.I often tell teams: â€œWe earn the right to do ML by getting the basics right first.â€2. As maturity builds, we focus on embedding analytics across the business â€” especially in risk, fraud, customer experience, and credit. This is where a strong layer of product analysts and embedded BI starts driving tangible business impact.3. At scale, roles like data product managers, governance leads, and ML engineers become critical â€” not just to deliver models, but to ensure theyâ€™re explainable, monitored, and integrated into decision systems.And increasingly, weâ€™re seeing the need for platform thinking: building reusable data products, not just bespoke dashboards.AI-native tools are already reshaping whatâ€™s possible, but I believe the core value still lies in clarity, trust, and alignment between data and business goals.ğŸ’¡No one structure fits all â€” but understanding your current stage helps you build the right team, at the right time, to deliver real impact.ğŸ«µAnd hey â€” if you made it to the end: Iâ€™m currently hiring. At scale, roles like data product managers, governance leads, and ML engineers become critical â€” not just to deliver models, but to ensure theyâ€™re explainable, monitored, and integrated into decision systems.And increasingly, weâ€™re seeing the need for platform thinking: building reusable data products, not just bespoke dashboards.AI-native tools are already reshaping whatâ€™s possible, but I believe the core value still lies in clarity, trust, and alignment between data and business goals.ğŸ’¡No one structure fits all â€” but understanding your current stage helps you build the right team, at the right time, to deliver real impact.ğŸ«µAnd hey â€” if you made it to the end: Iâ€™m currently hiring. âœï¸The structure of high-performing data teams is evolving â€” and context is everything.ğŸ§ As a CDO in the banking sector, I see firsthand how the right data team composition depends heavily on company size, regulatory environment, and data maturity.The recent benchmark shared on the balance between Insights (46%), Data Engineering (43%), and Machine Learning (11%) resonates â€” but Iâ€™d add a few reflections based on experience leading data transformations in both traditional and digital banking environments:1. In early maturity stages, especially in highly regulated industries like banking, data engineering and governance are foundational. Without robust pipelines, metadata management, lineage tracking, and data quality controls, insights are unreliable â€” and regulatory risk increases.I often tell teams: â€œWe earn the right to do ML by getting the basics right first.â€2. As maturity builds, we focus on embedding analytics across the business â€” especially in risk, fraud, customer experience, and credit. This is where a strong layer of product analysts and embedded BI starts driving tangible business impact.3. At scale, roles like data product managers, governance leads, and ML engineers become critical â€” not just to deliver models, but to ensure theyâ€™re explainable, monitored, and integrated into decision systems.And increasingly, weâ€™re seeing the need for platform thinking: building reusable data products, not just bespoke dashboards.AI-native tools are already reshaping whatâ€™s possible, but I believe the core value still lies in clarity, trust, and alignment between data and business goals.ğŸ’¡No one structure fits all â€” but understanding your current stage helps you build the right team, at the right time, to deliver real impact.ğŸ«µAnd hey â€” if you made it to the end: Iâ€™m currently hiring. âœï¸The structure of high-performing data teams is evolving â€” and context is everything.ğŸ§ As a CDO in the banking sector, I see firsthand how the right data team composition depends heavily on company size, regulatory environment, and data maturity.The recent benchmark shared on the balance between Insights (46%), Data Engineering (43%), and Machine Learning (11%) resonates â€” but Iâ€™d add a few reflections based on experience leading data transformations in both traditional and digital banking environments:1. In early maturity stages, especially in highly regulated industries like banking, data engineering and governance are foundational. Without robust pipelines, metadata management, lineage tracking, and data quality controls, insights are unreliable â€” and regulatory risk increases.I often tell teams: â€œWe earn the right to do ML by getting the basics right first.â€2. As maturity builds, we focus on embedding analytics across the business â€” especially in risk, fraud, customer experience, and credit. This is where a strong layer of product analysts and embedded BI starts driving tangible business impact.3. At scale, roles like data product managers, governance leads, and ML engineers become critical â€” not just to deliver models, but to ensure theyâ€™re explainable, monitored, and integrated into decision systems.And increasingly, weâ€™re seeing the need for platform thinking: building reusable data products, not just bespoke dashboards.AI-native tools are already reshaping whatâ€™s possible, but I believe the core value still lies in clarity, trust, and alignment between data and business goals.ğŸ’¡No one structure fits all â€” but understanding your current stage helps you build the right team, at the right time, to deliver real impact.ğŸ«µAnd hey â€” if you made it to the end: Iâ€™m currently hiring. Weâ€™re building something exciting, and Iâ€™m looking for data stewards, data engineers, and data scientists to join our team.DM me if youâ€™re curious.hashtag#CDO hashtag#BankingInnovation hashtag#DataGovernance hashtag#AnalyticsEngineering hashtag#DataStrategy hashtag#DataLeadership hashtag#AIinBanking

âœï¸The structure of high-performing data teams is evolving â€” and context is everything.ğŸ§ As a CDO in the banking sector, I see firsthand how the right data team composition depends heavily on company size, regulatory environment, and data maturity.The recent benchmark shared on the balance between Insights (46%), Data Engineering (43%), and Machine Learning (11%) resonates â€” but Iâ€™d add a few reflections based on experience leading data transformations in both traditional and digital banking environments:1. In early maturity stages, especially in highly regulated industries like banking, data engineering and governance are foundational. Without robust pipelines, metadata management, lineage tracking, and data quality controls, insights are unreliable â€” and regulatory risk increases.I often tell teams: â€œWe earn the right to do ML by getting the basics right first.â€2. As maturity builds, we focus on embedding analytics across the business â€” especially in risk, fraud, customer experience, and credit. This is where a strong layer of product analysts and embedded BI starts driving tangible business impact.3. At scale, roles like data product managers, governance leads, and ML engineers become critical â€” not just to deliver models, but to ensure theyâ€™re explainable, monitored, and integrated into decision systems.And increasingly, weâ€™re seeing the need for platform thinking: building reusable data products, not just bespoke dashboards.AI-native tools are already reshaping whatâ€™s possible, but I believe the core value still lies in clarity, trust, and alignment between data and business goals.ğŸ’¡No one structure fits all â€” but understanding your current stage helps you build the right team, at the right time, to deliver real impact.ğŸ«µAnd hey â€” if you made it to the end: Iâ€™m currently hiring. âœï¸The structure of high-performing data teams is evolving â€” and context is everything.ğŸ§ As a CDO in the banking sector, I see firsthand how the right data team composition depends heavily on company size, regulatory environment, and data maturity.The recent benchmark shared on the balance between Insights (46%), Data Engineering (43%), and Machine Learning (11%) resonates â€” but Iâ€™d add a few reflections based on experience leading data transformations in both traditional and digital banking environments:1. In early maturity stages, especially in highly regulated industries like banking, data engineering and governance are foundational. Without robust pipelines, metadata management, lineage tracking, and data quality controls, insights are unreliable â€” and regulatory risk increases.I often tell teams: â€œWe earn the right to do ML by getting the basics right first.â€2. As maturity builds, we focus on embedding analytics across the business â€” especially in risk, fraud, customer experience, and credit. This is where a strong layer of product analysts and embedded BI starts driving tangible business impact.3. At scale, roles like data product managers, governance leads, and ML engineers become critical â€” not just to deliver models, but to ensure theyâ€™re explainable, monitored, and integrated into decision systems.And increasingly, weâ€™re seeing the need for platform thinking: building reusable data products, not just bespoke dashboards.AI-native tools are already reshaping whatâ€™s possible, but I believe the core value still lies in clarity, trust, and alignment between data and business goals.ğŸ’¡No one structure fits all â€” but understanding your current stage helps you build the right team, at the right time, to deliver real impact.ğŸ«µAnd hey â€” if you made it to the end: Iâ€™m currently hiring. Without robust pipelines, metadata management, lineage tracking, and data quality controls, insights are unreliable â€” and regulatory risk increases.I often tell teams: â€œWe earn the right to do ML by getting the basics right first.â€2. At scale, roles like data product managers, governance leads, and ML engineers become critical â€” not just to deliver models, but to ensure theyâ€™re explainable, monitored, and integrated into decision systems.And increasingly, weâ€™re seeing the need for platform thinking: building reusable data products, not just bespoke dashboards.AI-native tools are already reshaping whatâ€™s possible, but I believe the core value still lies in clarity, trust, and alignment between data and business goals.ğŸ’¡No one structure fits all â€” but understanding your current stage helps you build the right team, at the right time, to deliver real impact.ğŸ«µAnd hey â€” if you made it to the end: Iâ€™m currently hiring.
